1959,"I've only had it about a week, and it has been constant troubleshooting.  When it works, I like the keyboard, the display is crisp and it boots up fast and switches tasks quickly.  But things didn't (and some still don't) work out of the box, and there is too much spamware installed.The right click on the touchpad did not function out of the box.  I researched a bit, couldn't find a good solution, but after I did a BIOS update for a different problem it seems to work now, although with a fiddly two finger gesture instead of just one finger clicking in the bottom right like every other laptop I've got.  It is a dice roll whether it registers both fingers or not, so you might get the right click menu, you might just open links or jump to somewhere else in the program and then have to get back and try again.  I'm guessing I'd get used to this.You do get Windows pre-installed.  The license key is a bit hard to find in case you need/want to reinstall it, but you can find it in the BIOS.  It boots real fast, so it is tricky to get to the BIOS menu.  Windows also doesn't seem to actually shut down, so when you open up the lid, it is already past the BIOS prompt (with the default settings).  Microsoft requires a Microsoft account to even use the computer, which isn't Lenovo's fault, but annoying.  Lenovo comes with ""helpful"" admin tools to update firmware and the BIOS, but you have to set up a Lenovo account to do so.  That is a pain, and I exited out, only to see that I've got an email verifying my Lenovo account, apparently populating it with info from the Microsoft account that I just set up.  I don't want to be paranoid, but Microsoft had me set up an account and five minutes later my information is being used to set up other accounts.  Not a good look for either side - how am I supposed to trust anything I do on this laptop?But even worse is the Lenovo software is like continuously being asked about your car's extended warranty, warning you about all the bad things that will happen and upselling you on better support.  How many people are buying a $500 laptop and needing on-site replacement services?The biggest problem by far is that I still don't know what the USB-C port does.  I initially set it up using my docking station.  USB-C charging didn't work.  It didn't recognize a second display.  It did recognize the ethernet connection and mouse and keyboard.  Reading up, it looks like it is fiddly with exactly which docking stations it will talk to.  I'm currently leaving one job, starting another, and for . . . reasons . . . , I currently have 5 daily use laptops, all of which work flawlessly with a ""high end"" Dell docking station.  I also have a ton of cheap ones from the last year hooking up school Chromebooks to various monitors.  None of them work with this Lenovo.  It will recognize the second display if I plug in the HDMI cable directly.  I have also tried any number of adapters to plug into the USB-C port - from Chromebooks, from a MacBookPro, from a dedicated USB charging hub that far exceeds the power requirements - no luck.  It doesn't recognize any of them to charge.  It does have a second charging port with a dedicated, proprietary connector which works well enough, but the brick that plugs to the wall is large and the cord is short-ish and the charging port is on one side of the machine only, which limits where I can actually use it.Speaking of which, the battery is nowhere near the 8.5 hours advertised.  More like 4, with the settings out of the box.  That is enough for me, but I had 75% charge left, suspended the computer and closed the lid, and it was completely empty 6 hours later.  I'm not sure you could be doing anything less with the computer, and it still drained the battery pretty quickly.  I've played with disabling some BIOS settings but don't see a huge difference.  If I don't have it plugged in overnight, it is dead in the morning.Other than that, no problems :)  I actually like the computer when it is running, it is much better than the one I am replacing, performance-wise.  But things did not work out of the box, and having a half-baked USB-C port that doesn't charge is probably a deal breaker for me.  I'm waiting on another docking station that has been reported to work well with this laptop before throwing away the days of configuration and returning it.  Who knows, maybe I just got a bum USB port and it does work out of the box for everyone else."

1972,"This is a long review.  To summarize, you get what you pay for and then some.  This is a very usable package at a bargain price.  Nothing is top-of-the-line, but you will get a nice, compact machine for web-based activity.This is my first Chromebook.  Previously I have used Macs and laptops from Toshiba and Lenovo.  I decided to go with a Chromebook because I mostly email, browse pages, Zoom, and watch Youtube.  Anything I need to do document-wise can be covered by Google.  The compactness and long battery life is a big plus.  I'm tired of big, heavy laptops wearing holes in my bags.This Chromebook weighs 2-1/4 .lbs, which is excellent.  It is about the size of a magazine, so I would not hestitate to take it anywhere.  The body is plastic, which is durable and easy to keep clean.  It's not as nice as metal, but it is generally solid.  The bottom panel is a teeny bit loose, but that is a nitpick.Battery life is as advertised.  Depending what you do you get around 10 hours or more, which is more than double any laptop I have used.The screen opens to 135 degrees (or 45 degrees against the tabletop).  I was disappointed it did not open to a full 180, but I can work with it.  Screen brightness is listed at 220 nits (on the low end), but don't let that deter you; it is as bright as my 8 year old Macbook and my Lenovo laptop assigned by work. For indoor use, it works just fine.  If you work outside, you will have to find shade.  The display quality is not the best, but perfectly useable.  It is an IPS display, which provides better viewing angles and color rendition.  The 11.6"" screen is enough real estate for watching videos and reading the news.  I can type this review and read my email side by side.  This is also a touch screen, which seems to work fine in my limited experience.  When laying down with the Chromebook on my chest, it's nice to just browse using the touchscreen.  I have downloaded a few Android games, and they work great on the touchscreen.  IMO spend more for the touch screen if you want to use Android apps.The keyboard is a comfortable size.  I am typing efficiently without making lots of mistakes.  Most of the keys are where you expect them to be.  The specialized Chrome keys don't interfere.  The keys themselves have a nice, positive response.  Equally responsive is the trackpad, which comes with a full repertoire of gestures for scrolling, zooming, and viewing apps.  One thing I noticed is you can only physically click on the botton half of the touchpad, but I usually tap to click.The on-board speakers are a nice surprise.  They are loud and clear.  An audiophile might find them slightly tinny, but I can listen to music for hours using just these speakers.  There is minimal distortion when I crank the volume up to max. Of course, there is a headphone jack and bluetooth capability.32 gigs of memory may be challenged if you install a lot of apps.  The Chrome System takes up about 13 GB on its own. I have inserted a 128 GB Micro SD card, which can be used as storage for Android apps that support it.  For example, I can download music from Youtube Music to my SD card.  Documents from the Text editor and Camera app can be directed to the SD card as well.Regarding the processor, I don't do anything that has taxed this system yet.  I usually only have a couple of tabs and apps open, and I play a few games.  Keep in mind this is the same processor on the almost universally lauded Lenovo Duet Chromebook, so it is no slouch.The 720p webcam is adquate for web conferencing, taking snapshots or recording videos.  It's a little grainy with indoor lighting.  People seem to hear me fine using the internal microphone, but works best if you are sitting right in front of the computer.  The mic input can be adjusted if you expand the volume options in the wifi/battery/time options.One last cool thing is you can charge this Chromebook with a phone charger (with the right cable).  It is slow, and must be done while the Chromebook is not in use.  I was able to get 15% per hour using a basic phone charger.  It might be nice if you are traveling and don't need to lug around the clunky power supply that comes with this Chromebook.Overall, I am happy with my purchase. This is a nice value package that delivers."
1973,"I first want to say that mechanically this laptop worked great. The company that sent it also sent it very fast, arriving ahead of the projected date. Do you have a phone? Well, your phone is capable of everything this device can do and more. You cannot even attempt to download them. I have heard that you can download apps (not that i was able to experience this for myself), but that will be the only downloading of programs that you might have access to.This now leads to my final gripe, the device is basically online only.A browser cannot function without internet, so it is with this device. It seems to be so dependent on this that it actually bugged out when i tried to delete the only wifi connection it had. (which reminds me, there is no way that you can factory reset this device. There is no option to do so, take that as you will.) When you first start up this device, it will force you to connect to the internet. It kept switching profiles when it felt like it not matter what I did.I resorted to reset it. but BOOM armoury crate was still embedded in the OS and there was no way around it.Third time's a charm right. I removed the M.2 and formatted that bad boy. It then refused to read it. Simple fix for that. Had to change a Bios setting to make it readable. Finally got the OS installed WITHOUT the Asus ARMOURY Crate.I saw IMMEDIATE improvement. with the proper settings and controlling the power setting and performance settings indpendent of the appit's an ok PC. Steadily at 70-80 FPS which is manageable given it's low Ram specs.Final thought - if you are a beginner int the PC world and are lookng to game on this, DO NOT BUY IT. Get a different brand. IT will be a headache if you choose to proceed. I'm pretty computer savvy and it took me all of a month to get it to decentIf it's for work GO AHEAD. It's a BEAST on that endIf it's for streaming, DO NOT BUY. With my capture card and Vmix software I kept getting horrible lags and the GPU timings were all the way at 17ms. ETERNITY if all you're doing is video blogging.If ASUS fixes the armoury crate or at least make it optional, this PC can be better. I'll then improve my rating but because of that. 2 stars is all it gets."

2049,"We purchased the refurbished toughbook for automotive shop use. I was a bit leery about buying a refurb unit due to a prior bad experience with another vendor. The unit arrived in better shape than expected. It arrived quickly and we were impressed with it's functionality and abilities. The real test and most impressive part of the purchase came a few days later when the unit would not boot up. My heart sank,here we go again. We called the tech line and surprisingly a person answered who was knowledgeable and courteous. He apologized for the issue and began instructing my technician how to trouble shoot the problem. Within a few minutes it was determined that a stick of ram was faulty. He instructed my tech to remove the one stick of ram as the unit would function with one of the 8 meg sticks removed. Once that was done the unit started and functioned. The person then promised to ship us a replacement immediately, which he did. The replacement stick arrived within 2 days. That's how service should be. Excellent company to deal with and we are looking forward to purchasing another unit from them. It's nice to see a company care about what they are selling and are willing to stand behind their product. Great job!! Highly recommended."
2050,"This laptop looks vaguely like a VCR from the 1980's. It isn't thin or particularly compact, but it's great. I've had bad luck with the last 3 laptops I've had... the battery in one of them was trying to start a fire (the battery was not replaceable), the other two just suddenly stopped working... and they were pricey gaming laptops. I gave up on laptops for awhile.This one caught my attention in a facebook ad, if for nothing other than how unique it looked. Wasn't even aware Panasonic made laptops. Saw that it was highly rated, thought it over, decided to give it a chance.First, about the laptop itself. I haven't done any torture tests, nor do I intend to... but I would guess that this laptop does live up to its name, ""Toughbook."" It isn't thin or graceful or elegant, it doesn't apologize for taking up space. It's beefy. I love it. The keyboard feels great, as does the area I rest my wrists on while typing. Perhaps the one thing I love the most about it is that If you look at the underside, you'll see a number of removable panels. Unlike many modern laptops, these are made to be fixable with replaceable parts.On to the refurb job. If this looks used, it is very gentle use. It's clean, the keys don't seem worn down,  I don't see any cosmetic flaws that stand out. I'm not sure I would say it feels new... but that may be because it looks like something from the 1980's. It has the feel of an old friend. Windows 10 was already installed, and most of the steps it makes you go through when you get a new computer had already been done, which is kinda nice - that can be pretty time consuming, and it can kill your bandwidth while its downloading dozens of updates in the background.It arrived quickly, in good shape, and included an AC adapter and a rather nice carry bag for travel."

2079,"Now let me preface this by being clear. I am an undergraduate computer science student. My father pretty much gave this computer to me as a gift during Christmas just for something to take notes on. I use the Whiteboard app a lot in fact to be able to take notes on it. I understand that you could type out the notes on a computer or whatever but I prefer using a notebook but at the same time I need to know what I'm writing about and a notebook can only grant me so much space. So this may not be a device for everyone but it is for me at least for the version I got.After two months with this product I could safely say this is a very good product that Microsoft has made. I have used it a little for drawing here and there and it does a fine job and for note-taking it's a great device with a bit of flaws.Goods*The screen is extremely high-quality. The gloss may turn some people off but I think it's great it does get a little dusty but that's easy to clean up.*The mouse pad is great. It reminds me of the MacBook mouse pad but it's much more responsive and smooth.*The keyboard took me time to get used to, especially considering this is the first time I ever used the laptop without any num keys.*The speakers get as loud as I want them to be but audio definitely sounds crisp and extremely high quality.*The way that the device switches from laptop mode to tablet mode is pretty simple for the most part, there is one thing that however concerns me but I'll get to that later I like the little bit of tilt that it has on the upper level because it gives me a better elevation to where I want to write.*The magnets are really helpful and strong when it comes to me putting the pen close to the computer.Bads*The battery life because it runs out very fast whenever I'm using the device like I was in class for 50 minutes one time and it drained very fast. I was at full100% battery and at the end of class it drained to 36%.*No USB ports I know more devices are using the USB C Port right now but the limited amount of the USB option really does bug me personally considering that I still have more devices that uses a standard USB cable over a USB C I understand that I could probably buy an adapter for that or whatever but it would have been nice to have more options for the device rather than just 2 USB C port. I'm not saying they should go all in and include two USB ports on the left and one on the right but at least one would have been nice.*There's no way to lay the screen flat on the table in tablet mode. This is one of the biggest problems because one thing I liked about other surface devices is that they would allow me to position the device anyway I wanted. However with this one you don't get as many options all you get was the flat bit tilted tablet mode and a viewing mode as you could say. This brings me to the biggest problem with the device and this may sound minor to many people but for me it kind of scares me.*The tablet to laptop mode hinges scares me to the point where I think if I bend it enough it's going to break. I'm not sure when it will happen but I will make sure to update people when it does. Because the device looks very sensitive and again it scares me and I usually don't get scared of this type of thing but I am for this one. When I am writing or drawing I exert a lot of pressure on a table surface or notebook that is how I feel comfortable when I write or draw and on this device I get scared every time I do something like that.*It is a little overpriced for it's specs and functionality.  256gb ssd is good but for $1,500 that's too much. Considering that there are laptops with the same functionality and better specs this was a bit expensive for what it is.Overall this is a great device may not be for everyone but it is great non the less for me. It will not automatically replace a tablet for those that have one and may not be the best tool for artist. But considering that there are people that may want a device that has the same functions of a tablet but also be able to use it as a computer this is a very good device for them if they are ok with the pricing. Keep in mind the version that I bought was not ment for gaming I didn't buy it to play video games, so for those that are getting this there is gonna be alot of restrictions when it comes to gaming."

I think these things can be remedied by doing a bit more research on measures to conserve battery life and purchasing a screen cleaning kit. Overall, I recommend this laptop for anyone looking to purchase something well-made, easy-to-use and under $800."

The first one had the issue, I returned it, but then the second one had it too.Believe it or not:  installing Google Chrome can make the OLED screen fail.  (See picture.)I know this because I accidentally noticed the screen 'failed' when I installed Chrome on the first one.  I observed this anecdotally, not actually blaming Chrome.  So I returned that laptop, ordered a 2nd one, and that screen crashed PRECISELY when I installed Google Chrome.That is evidence that it's a software problem, not the OLED.  So I Googled 'Chrome breaks my Asus laptop screen' and Asus offers you advice on how to turn off 'hardware acceleration'.(It's easy, anyone can do it.  Go here -- rb.gy/riuezq)  It also claims this same issue can be triggered by their own Edge browser and by Microsoft Office.  Turn off hardware acceleration and you're all set.  I'm going to 'test' this unit to make sure it's fixed but it sure seems so.  (I told you it was weird.)I suspect others are not reporting this (yet) because they haven't updated to Windows 11 yet, which this unit can do."

2172,"I recently ordered five ‚Äúrenewed‚Äù iPad Air 2 tablets through Amazon.¬†¬†The Air 2 was, and still is, one of the best iPad designs.¬†¬†So good, in fact, that the first iPad Pro 9.7 (2018) was really just an updated Air 2 and shared the same thin construction, laminated 9.7-inch Retina display, and overall size.¬†¬†The Air 2 has supported seven iOS updates and currently runs the latest iPadOS¬†14 ‚Äìtalk about longevity.¬† Over 2 million iPad Air 2 models were sold during its two year production that ended in early 2017.¬†Since you can no longer buy a new Air 2, the only option is used/refurbished.¬† Apple devices like the iPad are remarkably durable and buying refurbished is a great way to find a ""like new"" device that will last you many years to come.¬† It's a good value, too: When the Air 2 was originally released, the models ranged from $500-$700.¬† A few years later, you can buy the same models renewed for $200-$300 --a great deal for a device that's still state-of-the-art.¬†There's¬†no shortage of vendors for renewed/refurbished iPads but one thing is clear:¬†¬†‚ÄúRenewed, like new‚Äù is a broad term that covers everything from near-mint condition to laughingly-damaged devices.¬†¬†Some vendors are better, others are worse,¬†none will be perfect.¬†¬†Here‚Äôs my experience shopping over the past month:¬†Vendor #1:¬†¬†All Out Apple¬†I purchased two iPad Air 2‚Äôs from this seller, one 32GB and one 64GB.¬†¬†Both arrived in good condition, packaged safely, and they work fine.¬†¬†The¬†cosmetic defects are OK --a few light scratches and discoloration on the back of the case on one and a few nicks and shallow dent on the back of the other.¬†¬†When held at ‚Äúarm‚Äôs length‚Äù per Amazon's criteria the issues are not that visible.¬†¬†The display/touchscreenS are fine.¬†¬†The batteries in each last the normal 8 or so hours under typical use. The vendor includes a decent 2.4A (12W) USB charger and cable with each device similar to¬†the original iPad charger for fast charging times.¬†¬†Vendor #2:¬†¬†Platinum Deals[UPDATED 3/6/21:  I purchased four iPad Air 2‚Äôs from this seller, three 32GB and one 64GB.¬†¬†One of the 32GB arrived in close to ""like new"" condition.¬†¬†The cosmetic defects were minimal, however, after two weeks use, I noticed that a portion of the display backlight would flicker when set to the lowest brightness setting --the sign of a failing LED in the backlight.  I returned this iPad for another from same seller and the replacement works fine so far.  However, the cosmetic condition of the replacement is not as good as the first one since there are noticeable blemishes all the way around the aluminum bezel and there are a couple light scratches on the surface of the display glass.]  The other two iPads were, unfortunately, a totally¬†different story:¬† each one was delivered literally bent in the middle --not dented but actually deformed, as in the device was not flat!¬† This had nothing to do with shipping since the devices were¬†well-packed and the boxes were undamaged.¬† The deformation on each device distorted the display glass and it was easy to¬†see the permanent distortion when viewing along the edge of the device.¬† On one iPad, the deformation was severe enough to cause backlight distortion that¬†showed up as bright spots along the edge of the LCD (see photos).¬† The fact that the refurbisher considered these two bent iPads to be ""renewed, like new"" is both hilarious and sad.¬† Of course, both of the bent iPads went right back in their boxes for return to Amazon (I put a bright yellow post-it on each one to hopefully warn whoever inspects the returned devices not to turn around and sell them again.)¬† This vendor also included different USB chargers (either 8W or 12W USB-A or, incorrectly, one of them was USB-C) and cable with each device so they are not consistent --the 12W charger is the correct one for faster charging times.  I do give the vendor credit for immediately sending me the correct charger to replace the wrong USB-C charger delivered with one of the Air 2 units.ADVICE:  So, my advice is to inspect your ""renewed"" iPad carefully since the vendors are not consistent in the overall condition of what they'll send you.¬† The iPad Air 2, in particular, is remarkably thin and perhaps more prone to getting bent if mishandled during its life --perhaps explaining why bent ones find their way to a refurbisher in the first place.  The Air 2 has a wide tolerance for being bent and still work without a problem. However, it's quite clear that ""like new"" may not necessarily mean ""not bent"" for the ultra-thin Air 2 so use the 90-day Amazon Renewed Guarantee wisely to make sure your renewed device meets a reasonable definition of ""like new"" upon receipt.Overall, I'm happy with the two renewed iPads I decided to keep (32GB models, one from each vendor listed above).¬† I'm not sure that¬†any one vendor does a¬†better¬†job in selecting ""like new"" iPads but clearly, one of the above did not have an issue sending two bent iPads.Finally, be aware that the 90-day Amazon Renewed Guarantee says you'll get a full refund if not satisfied, however, some of the refurb vendors claim to charge return shipping and restocking fees.¬† The Amazon Renewed policy is not clear about this so if you're charged fees for the return then you should contact Amazon to have them correct it."

This was just a defective product with a ticking time bomb. Don't be tempted by the ""certified refurbished"" label. It is not the same as a manufacturer's certification, which typically does have rigorous standards and solid warranties. 2188,"First, let me say that I have the version with the 1650Ti, not the 3050. Mine also includes the Webcam, full RGB keyboard, and num pad. There is a slim version that does not have this.Now, I bought this laptop to replace my old daily driver that had a 1050. This laptop is miles better than that one in terms of image quality, GPU power, screen refresh, and sound.I've been using this laptop daily since I bought it. I added a 1TB SSD for storage, upgraded the RAM from the included 8GB to 32GB, and dropped the refresh rate to 60Hz to help battery life (which I will get to later).As far as this goes as a gaming laptop, I've been able to run everything I've thrown at it at max settings. Fallout 76 runs at a solid 48fps (its capped there for some strange reason) at max settings. Gears 5 runs at 60fps (again, capped) on max settings even with all the environment and snow particles. With the IPS display, these games look super good. Huge upgrade to my previous laptops TN display. The colors are absolutely crisp and deep.The sound quality is decent. It's not studio music quality, but it's definitely decent enough for gaming without any noticeable clipping issues. I'm able to discern bass, mid, and treble without a lot of muddiness. Obviously, it's not perfect as they are laptop speakers, but given that restriction, I'd say it does very well.Now, the only complaint I have is the battery life. It's nowhere near the advertised. My old laptop with adjusted settings reached 6-7 hours. This one with the same settings reaches only MAYBE 2. If you're playing a game, you'll be lucky to hit an hour. This is not a laptop to play on battery. The higher the graphic quality and the higher you keep the refresh rate (like the native 144hz) the worse it'll be. Even with dropping the refresh to 60 and playing a game that doesn't require the 1650Ti, it still only will last about an hour. Watching videos is longer, but that's still about 2 hours, give or take.Overall a good purchase provided you want it plugged in most of the time."

2192,"So I got this to play FF14 while I travel and am away from my actual gaming PC, and this does the job perfectly. It's just generally a really capable laptop -- handles streaming, gaming, did some remote work and calls on it np, etc.I love how lightweight and quiet it is.There was only one initial problem I had with it which would have been a deal breaker if there hadn't been such an easy solution -- while I was waiting in that 4k+ q that's the current reality (as of the EW expac), this pc's fans started going haywire.. SOOO loud, heated up, unacceptable. To fix: simply adjust your maximum power state. Docking it a mere 2% will stop it from making any insane noises and return it to the silent, smooth state it runs in when doing everything else (only had the problem when running games, but again super easy fix.  (if you don't know how to adjust this or what that means this is how you fix: Right click your lil battery icon, hit power options, next to the ""ASUS Recommended"" power plan click ""change plan settings"", ""change advanced power settings"", ""processor power management"", ""maximum power state"" -- reduce this from 100% to 98%. Problem solved, resume quiet, beautiful laptop fun)."

2194,"This is my first new Windows laptop in nearly eight years; the previous one is a Dell Inspiron 15R that has seen several upgrades and parts replaced but badly needed to be retired.  I had intended on getting an Inspiron 15 5510 with 16GB of RAM and a 1TB SSD but the price just wasn't right.  I settled for this system with the AMD Ryzen 7 and a 512GB SSD.Unboxing the laptop made me think I made a huge mistake.  This is much smaller than my 15R.  I knew thinness coming into it as well as weight; this is a full pound and a half lighter than the 15R, and that will go a long way in the future (more on that later).  It didn't look like a 15"" laptop, but it really is.The screen is a touchscreen.  I used it only once just to see how it worked.  It works.  I don't ever intend on using it ever again because I do not like fingerprints on my laptop screen and I don't think a touchscreen is a useful feature on a laptop.  It is a higher resolution screen than the 15R but it is not the best in the world.  Granted, my M1 MacBook Air has a smaller screen but it is so freaking sharp and amazing, so much so that I think it blows away every other laptop screen on the market.  The screen on this is not a dealbreaker; I don't intend on using the laptop to watch Netflix or any TV shows or whatnot.  It is going to be used exactly what a computer is intended to be used.The keyboard is really nice.  I had destroyed the original keyboard on the 15R and ordered a replacement off Amazon.  It was the loudest keyboard in the world and sometimes some keys just wouldn't type.  I also could not upgrade to a backlit one (again, another MacBook feature I love).  Both the 5510 and 5515 I was looking at had backlit keyboards, and that was a must-have for me.  This one is much quieter, exactly how a laptop keyboard should sound.  F5 to refresh needed to push the Fn key then F5, but then I learned through Google you can make it so that when you hit the refresh key you can make that a primary function.The power cord is a 65W AC adapter with a much smaller plug; not compatible with what I had for the 15R.  I'll be purchasing a second one for travel.  I'm not so sure I'll use the USB-C port to charge the battery and power the laptop while traveling.  I may end up doing that.In terms of USB ports and all, it's nice that there is an HDMI port, one USB-C, and two USB-A ports.  One of the big selling points for me was that it also had an SD card reader.  That in itself seems like something many laptops being sold in 2022 are being shipped without, forcing the user to buy a potentially costly SD card reader of some sort or USB-C multi-hub.  I wish I had one more USB-A port but that would probably add some weight to the laptop.  I'll be buying a pair of USB-A hubs at some point, one for home and one for travel, especially since I need one USB-A for a wireless mouse (though I might look into Bluetooth mice).Weight was another factor in the purchase.  I originally had my eye on the 5510 because it started at 3.6 pounds.  My 15R was somewhere around 5.1 pounds.  Let me say that this 5515 is a pleasure to carry around.  As a videographer who travels quite a bit by airline, my travel backpack weighs in around 30 pounds with a reduced camera load, which includes PC and Mac and accessories and your typical toiletries.  Making that bag 1.5 pounds lighter will feel real good.  I also had an eye on a custom build HP 15t-dy200, which weighed in around 3.8 pounds, but HP has a ton of issues with custom builds as per comments I've seen on Reddit.Finally, expandability.  I have a MacBook Air that I regret not having 16GB of RAM, but even with 8GB it is one hell of an amazing machine, one that no PC out there today could match.  The Dell Inspiron 15 5515 I got has 16GB of RAM and a 512GB SSD.  I really wanted a 1TB SSD but settled for the 512GB.  The memory can be expanded to a max of 32GB (two 16GB sticks) and I plan to do that in the future.  The real kicker is learning that the 5515 (and probably the 5510 as well) has room for a second SSD.  I plan to research this a little more because I definitely want to add a second SSD.  It's a type of SSD that I had never heard about until I researched it, and I'm pretty sure the second SSD can be no larger than 2TB.Overall, with writing this only 30 hours since it arrived, I really like this laptop.  I hope I can get many years out of this like I did with my previous Dell."

2205,"I figured 4GB of RAM would be sufficient just for day to day use. I was a bit disappointed in 128GB of storage and decided that even though it was a really nice machine for the price, for another $80 and change I could really make it fly.. if you look at my photos you can see that there's built in space for a 2.5 in SATA drive. In addition there is room to add memory and I decided to add another 8GB of RAM along with the SATA drive and 480 GB of storage. Obviously it makes a huge difference. If you look at the pictures I posted you can see that the Acer storage is depleted by half as soon as you turn the machine on. The Steve drive is the one that I installed. Plenty of storage now. The circled in red photo shows the increase in RAM... WHEN LOOKING FOR INSTRUCTIONS be aware that this model came out back in May of this year. There are very few instructional videos or written pieces to explain where this memory goes. The SATA drive is pretty self-explanatory. The only video I could find with this particular machine is provided by a user whose name is.  ¬†@Silicon Edge¬†  you have to go to YouTube and search that name. I don't believe Amazon would allow me to post a link. It's not in English but all you have to do is watch his hands. If you try other videos you might think it's the machine you've bought until you open the back of yours and you look at the back of theirs and realize that it's different. I highly recommend temporarily taking out the screw on your right side of the battery to secure the ribbon clip. Then just readjust the battery and put the screw back in. Watch the video you'll know exactly what I mean. I love this computer. For $460 including the new ram I upgraded this machine. It would have cost me way more than that to buy it with that memory and that storage from scratch. Quick PS. I bought an HP 27 inch monitor here on Amazon and created a nice little setup. $169. You'll love the machine Don't think twice just buy it. If you want some speed, I mean real speed just upgrade the RAM and the storage. I used crucial. That's the brand name for the SATA and the RAM..... READ ABOUT THE UPGRADES..... You don't want to perform Overkill. The processor wasn't made for it. I'm no techie so I did a lot of reading before I did this."

2210,"I did quite a bit of research before purchasing this laptop. It seemed like a good computer for the price. Many if the reviews said it was short on memory. It has a SSD drive but it is a bit on the small side, and the built in ram was lacking at only 4 gb. There is an open slot for ram and a space for a second hard drive already there. The company included a pack of hard drive screws with a web site to instruct you on how to install a second drive. Since I had a like new 1tb laptop drive and a 8gb memory card laying around, I waisted no time. The upgrade was simple.Honestly, I have no complaints with this laptop. Some people complained about the screen. I don't know why, it's very clear to me. Battery life is fine, but I am just a home user so I am not on it for hours at a time. The speakers point down from under the computer, but I can still hear what I need to so no big deal to me. I even don't mind the touch pad on this one (hated the one on my last computer).If you are a gamer or someone who needs a super powerful computer for intense graphics, this probably isn't your best choice. But for home use, I am very happy with this laptop and would certainly recommend it."

2237,"This zippy laptop has a great screen, nice keyboard/trackpad, good battery, lightweight, plenty of RAM and storage -- an excellent budget 15.6 inch laptop. The real problem (which can be easily fixed by you) is super WEIRD.  I've purchased two of these.  The first one had the issue, I returned it, but then the second one had it too.Believe it or not:  installing Google Chrome can make the OLED screen fail.  (See picture.)I know this because I accidentally noticed the screen 'failed' when I installed Chrome on the first one.  I observed this anecdotally, not actually blaming Chrome.  So I returned that laptop, ordered a 2nd one, and that screen crashed PRECISELY when I installed Google Chrome.That is evidence that it's a software problem, not the OLED.  So I Googled 'Chrome breaks my Asus laptop screen' and Asus offers you advice on how to turn off 'hardware acceleration'.(It's easy, anyone can do it.  Go here -- rb.gy/riuezq)  It also claims this same issue can be triggered by their own Edge browser and by Microsoft Office.  Turn off hardware acceleration and you're all set.  I'm going to 'test' this unit to make sure it's fixed but it sure seems so.  (I told you it was weird.)I suspect others are not reporting this (yet) because they haven't updated to Windows 11 yet, which this unit can do."

2246,"I bought this machine to act as a portable home server. Its entire function is to run my automation programs 24/7. So the way I use it will most likely be far different from the average consumer. That being said upfront, here are the pros and cons I've run into so far.Pros:- Thunderbolt 4- Compact and lightweight- 11th gen Intel i5- The new Iris Pro graphics- Small bevel on the screen- Charges up fast- Upgradable RAM & M.2- Boots insanely fast (1.8 seconds)- Trackpad is very sturdy and niceCons:- Weak keyboard backlighting- Sound isn't very good (it's a tiny laptop, come on)- Light bleed around the top corners of the screen- Exhaust ports are directly behind the kbd - not on the bottom of the laptop- McAffee A/V is integrated several ways on the OS (more on this below)- Squishy keysConclusion:For $665 this is a decent laptop for my purposes. It sits on my desk with the screen closed, and I access it via remote desktop. I put a $35 laptop cooling pad underneath it, which as it turns out is worthless because there are no exhaust fans on the bottom of the unit.The keys were more squishy than I thought they'd be, and the backlight on the keyboard is very weak. On the flip side, the trackpad is actually very good. It has a fingerprint scanner built-in, and it's pretty accurate so far.There's considerable light bleed when the background is set to all black, and I was pretty shocked it was actually that bad. Luckily for me, I won't be using the screen all that much. I still might return it because of this, I'm on the fence about it.McAffee A/V is nested pretty deep in the operating system. I had to use Revo Pro to get rid of all traces of it, and it tried its best to fight back. There are folders on the C drive for the A/V which cannot be removed, even as the administrator, and that's no bueno.But is it fast? Yeah. It boots in 1.8 seconds, it ran my photoshop no problem, as well as my automation programs without a hitch (which are pretty cpu/ram intensive). I didn't try playing any games with it, as this is more of a creators/business type of machine. 2279,"I recently ordered five ‚Äúrenewed‚Äù iPad Air 2 tablets through Amazon.¬†¬†The Air 2 was, and still is, one of the best iPad designs.¬†¬†So good, in fact, that the first iPad Pro 9.7 (2018) was really just an updated Air 2 and shared the same thin construction, laminated 9.7-inch Retina display, and overall size.¬†¬†The Air 2 has supported seven iOS updates and currently runs the latest iPadOS¬†14 ‚Äìtalk about longevity.¬† Over 2 million iPad Air 2 models were sold during its two year production that ended in early 2017.¬†Since you can no longer buy a new Air 2, the only option is used/refurbished.¬† Apple devices like the iPad are remarkably durable and buying refurbished is a great way to find a ""like new"" device that will last you many years to come.¬† It's a good value, too: When the Air 2 was originally released, the models ranged from $500-$700.¬† A few years later, you can buy the same models renewed for $200-$300 --a great deal for a device that's still state-of-the-art.¬†There's¬†no shortage of vendors for renewed/refurbished iPads but one thing is clear:¬†¬†‚ÄúRenewed, like new‚Äù is a broad term that covers everything from near-mint condition to laughingly-damaged devices.¬†¬†Some vendors are better, others are worse,¬†none will be perfect.¬†¬†Here‚Äôs my experience shopping over the past month:¬†Vendor #1:¬†¬†All Out Apple¬†I purchased two iPad Air 2‚Äôs from this seller, one 32GB and one 64GB.¬†¬†Both arrived in good condition, packaged safely, and they work fine.¬†¬†The¬†cosmetic defects are OK --a few light scratches and discoloration on the back of the case on one and a few nicks and shallow dent on the back of the other.¬†¬†When held at ‚Äúarm‚Äôs length‚Äù per Amazon's criteria the issues are not that visible.¬†¬†The display/touchscreenS are fine.¬†¬†The batteries in each last the normal 8 or so hours under typical use. The vendor includes a decent 2.4A (12W) USB charger and cable with each device similar to¬†the original iPad charger for fast charging times.¬†¬†Vendor #2:¬†¬†Platinum Deals[UPDATED 3/6/21:  I purchased four iPad Air 2‚Äôs from this seller, three 32GB and one 64GB.¬†¬†One of the 32GB arrived in close to ""like new"" condition.¬†¬†The cosmetic defects were minimal, however, after two weeks use, I noticed that a portion of the display backlight would flicker when set to the lowest brightness setting --the sign of a failing LED in the backlight.  I returned this iPad for another from same seller and the replacement works fine so far.  However, the cosmetic condition of the replacement is not as good as the first one since there are noticeable blemishes all the way around the aluminum bezel and there are a couple light scratches on the surface of the display glass.]  The other two iPads were, unfortunately, a totally¬†different story:¬† each one was delivered literally bent in the middle --not dented but actually deformed, as in the device was not flat!¬† This had nothing to do with shipping since the devices were¬†well-packed and the boxes were undamaged.¬† The deformation on each device distorted the display glass and it was easy to¬†see the permanent distortion when viewing along the edge of the device.¬† On one iPad, the deformation was severe enough to cause backlight distortion that¬†showed up as bright spots along the edge of the LCD (see photos).¬† The fact that the refurbisher considered these two bent iPads to be ""renewed, like new"" is both hilarious and sad.¬† Of course, both of the bent iPads went right back in their boxes for return to Amazon (I put a bright yellow post-it on each one to hopefully warn whoever inspects the returned devices not to turn around and sell them again.)¬† This vendor also included different USB chargers (either 8W or 12W USB-A or, incorrectly, one of them was USB-C) and cable with each device so they are not consistent --the 12W charger is the correct one for faster charging times.  I do give the vendor credit for immediately sending me the correct charger to replace the wrong USB-C charger delivered with one of the Air 2 units.ADVICE:  So, my advice is to inspect your ""renewed"" iPad carefully since the vendors are not consistent in the overall condition of what they'll send you.¬† The iPad Air 2, in particular, is remarkably thin and perhaps more prone to getting bent if mishandled during its life --perhaps explaining why bent ones find their way to a refurbisher in the first place.  The Air 2 has a wide tolerance for being bent and still work without a problem. However, it's quite clear that ""like new"" may not necessarily mean ""not bent"" for the ultra-thin Air 2 so use the 90-day Amazon Renewed Guarantee wisely to make sure your renewed device meets a reasonable definition of ""like new"" upon receipt.Overall, I'm happy with the two renewed iPads I decided to keep (32GB models, one from each vendor listed above).¬† I'm not sure that¬†any one vendor does a¬†better¬†job in selecting ""like new"" iPads but clearly, one of the above did not have an issue sending two bent iPads.Finally, be aware that the 90-day Amazon Renewed Guarantee says you'll get a full refund if not satisfied, however, some of the refurb vendors claim to charge return shipping and restocking fees.¬† The Amazon Renewed policy is not clear about this so if you're charged fees for the return then you should contact Amazon to have them correct it."

This was just a defective product with a ticking time bomb. Don't be tempted by the ""certified refurbished"" label. It is not the same as a manufacturer's certification, which typically does have rigorous standards and solid warranties. 2295,"First, let me say that I have the version with the 1650Ti, not the 3050. Mine also includes the Webcam, full RGB keyboard, and num pad. There is a slim version that does not have this.Now, I bought this laptop to replace my old daily driver that had a 1050. This laptop is miles better than that one in terms of image quality, GPU power, screen refresh, and sound.I've been using this laptop daily since I bought it. I added a 1TB SSD for storage, upgraded the RAM from the included 8GB to 32GB, and dropped the refresh rate to 60Hz to help battery life (which I will get to later).As far as this goes as a gaming laptop, I've been able to run everything I've thrown at it at max settings. Fallout 76 runs at a solid 48fps (its capped there for some strange reason) at max settings. Gears 5 runs at 60fps (again, capped) on max settings even with all the environment and snow particles. With the IPS display, these games look super good. Huge upgrade to my previous laptops TN display. The colors are absolutely crisp and deep.The sound quality is decent. It's not studio music quality, but it's definitely decent enough for gaming without any noticeable clipping issues. I'm able to discern bass, mid, and treble without a lot of muddiness. Obviously, it's not perfect as they are laptop speakers, but given that restriction, I'd say it does very well.Now, the only complaint I have is the battery life. It's nowhere near the advertised. My old laptop with adjusted settings reached 6-7 hours. This one with the same settings reaches only MAYBE 2. If you're playing a game, you'll be lucky to hit an hour. This is not a laptop to play on battery. The higher the graphic quality and the higher you keep the refresh rate (like the native 144hz) the worse it'll be. Even with dropping the refresh to 60 and playing a game that doesn't require the 1650Ti, it still only will last about an hour. Watching videos is longer, but that's still about 2 hours, give or take.Overall a good purchase provided you want it plugged in most of the time."

2299,"So I got this to play FF14 while I travel and am away from my actual gaming PC, and this does the job perfectly. It's just generally a really capable laptop -- handles streaming, gaming, did some remote work and calls on it np, etc.I love how lightweight and quiet it is.There was only one initial problem I had with it which would have been a deal breaker if there hadn't been such an easy solution -- while I was waiting in that 4k+ q that's the current reality (as of the EW expac), this pc's fans started going haywire.. SOOO loud, heated up, unacceptable. To fix: simply adjust your maximum power state. Docking it a mere 2% will stop it from making any insane noises and return it to the silent, smooth state it runs in when doing everything else (only had the problem when running games, but again super easy fix.  (if you don't know how to adjust this or what that means this is how you fix: Right click your lil battery icon, hit power options, next to the ""ASUS Recommended"" power plan click ""change plan settings"", ""change advanced power settings"", ""processor power management"", ""maximum power state"" -- reduce this from 100% to 98%. Problem solved, resume quiet, beautiful laptop fun)."

I had intended on getting an Inspiron 15 5510 with 16GB of RAM and a 1TB SSD but the price just wasn't right.  I settled for this system with the AMD Ryzen 7 and a 512GB SSD.Unboxing the laptop made me think I made a huge mistake.  This is much smaller than my 15R.  I knew thinness coming into it as well as weight; this is a full pound and a half lighter than the 15R, and that will go a long way in the future (more on that later).  It didn't look like a 15"" laptop, but it really is.The screen is a touchscreen.  I used it only once just to see how it worked.  It works.  I don't ever intend on using it ever again because I do not like fingerprints on my laptop screen and I don't think a touchscreen is a useful feature on a laptop.  It is a higher resolution screen than the 15R but it is not the best in the world.  Granted, my M1 MacBook Air has a smaller screen but it is so freaking sharp and amazing, so much so that I think it blows away every other laptop screen on the market.  The screen on this is not a dealbreaker; I don't intend on using the laptop to watch Netflix or any TV shows or whatnot.  It is going to be used exactly what a computer is intended to be used.The keyboard is really nice.  I had destroyed the original keyboard on the 15R and ordered a replacement off Amazon.  It was the loudest keyboard in the world and sometimes some keys just wouldn't type.  I also could not upgrade to a backlit one (again, another MacBook feature I love).  Both the 5510 and 5515 I was looking at had backlit keyboards, and that was a must-have for me.  This one is much quieter, exactly how a laptop keyboard should sound.  F5 to refresh needed to push the Fn key then F5, but then I learned through Google you can make it so that when you hit the refresh key you can make that a primary function.The power cord is a 65W AC adapter with a much smaller plug; not compatible with what I had for the 15R.  I'll be purchasing a second one for travel.  I'm not so sure I'll use the USB-C port to charge the battery and power the laptop while traveling.  I may end up doing that.In terms of USB ports and all, it's nice that there is an HDMI port, one USB-C, and two USB-A ports.  One of the big selling points for me was that it also had an SD card reader.  That in itself seems like something many laptops being sold in 2022 are being shipped without, forcing the user to buy a potentially costly SD card reader of some sort or USB-C multi-hub.  I wish I had one more USB-A port but that would probably add some weight to the laptop.  I'll be buying a pair of USB-A hubs at some point, one for home and one for travel, especially since I need one USB-A for a wireless mouse (though I might look into Bluetooth mice).Weight was another factor in the purchase.  I originally had my eye on the 5510 because it started at 3.6 pounds.  My 15R was somewhere around 5.1 pounds.  Let me say that this 5515 is a pleasure to carry around.  As a videographer who travels quite a bit by airline, my travel backpack weighs in around 30 pounds with a reduced camera load, which includes PC and Mac and accessories and your typical toiletries.  Making that bag 1.5 pounds lighter will feel real good.  I also had an eye on a custom build HP 15t-dy200, which weighed in around 3.8 pounds, but HP has a ton of issues with custom builds as per comments I've seen on Reddit.Finally, expandability.  I have a MacBook Air that I regret not having 16GB of RAM, but even with 8GB it is one hell of an amazing machine, one that no PC out there today could match.  The Dell Inspiron 15 5515 I got has 16GB of RAM and a 512GB SSD.  I really wanted a 1TB SSD but settled for the 512GB.  The memory can be expanded to a max of 32GB (two 16GB sticks) and I plan to do that in the future.  The real kicker is learning that the 5515 (and probably the 5510 as well) has room for a second SSD.  I plan to research this a little more because I definitely want to add a second SSD.  It's a type of SSD that I had never heard about until I researched it, and I'm pretty sure the second SSD can be no larger than 2TB.Overall, with writing this only 30 hours since it arrived, I really like this laptop.  I hope I can get many years out of this like I did with my previous Dell."

2312,"I figured 4GB of RAM would be sufficient just for day to day use. I was a bit disappointed in 128GB of storage and decided that even though it was a really nice machine for the price, for another $80 and change I could really make it fly.. if you look at my photos you can see that there's built in space for a 2.5 in SATA drive. In addition there is room to add memory and I decided to add another 8GB of RAM along with the SATA drive and 480 GB of storage. Obviously it makes a huge difference. If you look at the pictures I posted you can see that the Acer storage is depleted by half as soon as you turn the machine on. The Steve drive is the one that I installed. Plenty of storage now. The circled in red photo shows the increase in RAM... WHEN LOOKING FOR INSTRUCTIONS be aware that this model came out back in May of this year. There are very few instructional videos or written pieces to explain where this memory goes. The SATA drive is pretty self-explanatory. The only video I could find with this particular machine is provided by a user whose name is.  ¬†@Silicon Edge¬†  you have to go to YouTube and search that name. I don't believe Amazon would allow me to post a link. It's not in English but all you have to do is watch his hands. If you try other videos you might think it's the machine you've bought until you open the back of yours and you look at the back of theirs and realize that it's different. I highly recommend temporarily taking out the screw on your right side of the battery to secure the ribbon clip. Then just readjust the battery and put the screw back in. Watch the video you'll know exactly what I mean. I love this computer. For $460 including the new ram I upgraded this machine. It would have cost me way more than that to buy it with that memory and that storage from scratch. Quick PS. I bought an HP 27 inch monitor here on Amazon and created a nice little setup. $169. You'll love the machine Don't think twice just buy it. If you want some speed, I mean real speed just upgrade the RAM and the storage. I used crucial. That's the brand name for the SATA and the RAM..... READ ABOUT THE UPGRADES..... You don't want to perform Overkill. The processor wasn't made for it. I'm no techie so I did a lot of reading before I did this."

The first one had the issue, I returned it, but then the second one had it too.Believe it or not:  installing Google Chrome can make the OLED screen fail.  (See picture.)I know this because I accidentally noticed the screen 'failed' when I installed Chrome on the first one.  I observed this anecdotally, not actually blaming Chrome.  So I returned that laptop, ordered a 2nd one, and that screen crashed PRECISELY when I installed Google Chrome.That is evidence that it's a software problem, not the OLED.  So I Googled 'Chrome breaks my Asus laptop screen' and Asus offers you advice on how to turn off 'hardware acceleration'.(It's easy, anyone can do it.  Go here -- rb.gy/riuezq)  It also claims this same issue can be triggered by their own Edge browser and by Microsoft Office.  Turn off hardware acceleration and you're all set.  I'm going to 'test' this unit to make sure it's fixed but it sure seems so.  (I told you it was weird.)I suspect others are not reporting this (yet) because they haven't updated to Windows 11 yet, which this unit can do."

2353,"I bought this machine to act as a portable home server. Its entire function is to run my automation programs 24/7. So the way I use it will most likely be far different from the average consumer. That being said upfront, here are the pros and cons I've run into so far.Pros:- Thunderbolt 4- Compact and lightweight- 11th gen Intel i5- The new Iris Pro graphics- Small bevel on the screen- Charges up fast- Upgradable RAM & M.2- Boots insanely fast (1.8 seconds)- Trackpad is very sturdy and niceCons:- Weak keyboard backlighting- Sound isn't very good (it's a tiny laptop, come on)- Light bleed around the top corners of the screen- Exhaust ports are directly behind the kbd - not on the bottom of the laptop- McAffee A/V is integrated several ways on the OS (more on this below)- Squishy keysConclusion:For $665 this is a decent laptop for my purposes. It sits on my desk with the screen closed, and I access it via remote desktop. I put a $35 laptop cooling pad underneath it, which as it turns out is worthless because there are no exhaust fans on the bottom of the unit.The keys were more squishy than I thought they'd be, and the backlight on the keyboard is very weak. On the flip side, the trackpad is actually very good. It has a fingerprint scanner built-in, and it's pretty accurate so far.There's considerable light bleed when the background is set to all black, and I was pretty shocked it was actually that bad. Luckily for me, I won't be using the screen all that much. I still might return it because of this, I'm on the fence about it.McAffee A/V is nested pretty deep in the operating system. I had to use Revo Pro to get rid of all traces of it, and it tried its best to fight back. There are folders on the C drive for the A/V which cannot be removed, even as the administrator, and that's no bueno.But is it fast? Yeah. It boots in 1.8 seconds, it ran my photoshop no problem, as well as my automation programs without a hitch (which are pretty cpu/ram intensive). I didn't try playing any games with it, as this is more of a creators/business type of machine. I'm sure it would do fine on some basic games.My final score: 3/5My background: Microsoft Certified Professional - CompTIA - Degree in Networking - I.T. Project Manager"

2386,"I recently ordered five ‚Äúrenewed‚Äù iPad Air 2 tablets through Amazon.¬†¬†The Air 2 was, and still is, one of the best iPad designs.¬†¬†So good, in fact, that the first iPad Pro 9.7 (2018) was really just an updated Air 2 and shared the same thin construction, laminated 9.7-inch Retina display, and overall size.¬†¬†The Air 2 has supported seven iOS updates and currently runs the latest iPadOS¬†14 ‚Äìtalk about longevity.¬† Over 2 million iPad Air 2 models were sold during its two year production that ended in early 2017.¬†Since you can no longer buy a new Air 2, the only option is used/refurbished.¬† Apple devices like the iPad are remarkably durable and buying refurbished is a great way to find a ""like new"" device that will last you many years to come.¬† It's a good value, too: When the Air 2 was originally released, the models ranged from $500-$700.¬† A few years later, you can buy the same models renewed for $200-$300 --a great deal for a device that's still state-of-the-art.¬†There's¬†no shortage of vendors for renewed/refurbished iPads but one thing is clear:¬†¬†‚ÄúRenewed, like new‚Äù is a broad term that covers everything from near-mint condition to laughingly-damaged devices.¬†¬†Some vendors are better, others are worse,¬†none will be perfect.¬†¬†Here‚Äôs my experience shopping over the past month:¬†Vendor #1:¬†¬†All Out Apple¬†I purchased two iPad Air 2‚Äôs from this seller, one 32GB and one 64GB.¬†¬†Both arrived in good condition, packaged safely, and they work fine.¬†¬†The¬†cosmetic defects are OK --a few light scratches and discoloration on the back of the case on one and a few nicks and shallow dent on the back of the other.¬†¬†When held at ‚Äúarm‚Äôs length‚Äù per Amazon's criteria the issues are not that visible.¬†¬†The display/touchscreenS are fine.¬†¬†The batteries in each last the normal 8 or so hours under typical use. The vendor includes a decent 2.4A (12W) USB charger and cable with each device similar to¬†the original iPad charger for fast charging times.¬†¬†Vendor #2:¬†¬†Platinum Deals[UPDATED 3/6/21:  I purchased four iPad Air 2‚Äôs from this seller, three 32GB and one 64GB.¬†¬†One of the 32GB arrived in close to ""like new"" condition.¬†¬†The cosmetic defects were minimal, however, after two weeks use, I noticed that a portion of the display backlight would flicker when set to the lowest brightness setting --the sign of a failing LED in the backlight.  I returned this iPad for another from same seller and the replacement works fine so far.  However, the cosmetic condition of the replacement is not as good as the first one since there are noticeable blemishes all the way around the aluminum bezel and there are a couple light scratches on the surface of the display glass.]  The other two iPads were, unfortunately, a totally¬†different story:¬† each one was delivered literally bent in the middle --not dented but actually deformed, as in the device was not flat!¬† This had nothing to do with shipping since the devices were¬†well-packed and the boxes were undamaged.¬† The deformation on each device distorted the display glass and it was easy to¬†see the permanent distortion when viewing along the edge of the device.¬† On one iPad, the deformation was severe enough to cause backlight distortion that¬†showed up as bright spots along the edge of the LCD (see photos).¬† The fact that the refurbisher considered these two bent iPads to be ""renewed, like new"" is both hilarious and sad.¬† Of course, both of the bent iPads went right back in their boxes for return to Amazon (I put a bright yellow post-it on each one to hopefully warn whoever inspects the returned devices not to turn around and sell them again.)¬† This vendor also included different USB chargers (either 8W or 12W USB-A or, incorrectly, one of them was USB-C) and cable with each device so they are not consistent --the 12W charger is the correct one for faster charging times.  I do give the vendor credit for immediately sending me the correct charger to replace the wrong USB-C charger delivered with one of the Air 2 units.ADVICE:  So, my advice is to inspect your ""renewed"" iPad carefully since the vendors are not consistent in the overall condition of what they'll send you.¬† The iPad Air 2, in particular, is remarkably thin and perhaps more prone to getting bent if mishandled during its life --perhaps explaining why bent ones find their way to a refurbisher in the first place.  The Air 2 has a wide tolerance for being bent and still work without a problem. However, it's quite clear that ""like new"" may not necessarily mean ""not bent"" for the ultra-thin Air 2 so use the 90-day Amazon Renewed Guarantee wisely to make sure your renewed device meets a reasonable definition of ""like new"" upon receipt.Overall, I'm happy with the two renewed iPads I decided to keep (32GB models, one from each vendor listed above).¬† I'm not sure that¬†any one vendor does a¬†better¬†job in selecting ""like new"" iPads but clearly, one of the above did not have an issue sending two bent iPads.Finally, be aware that the 90-day Amazon Renewed Guarantee says you'll get a full refund if not satisfied, however, some of the refurb vendors claim to charge return shipping and restocking fees.¬† The Amazon Renewed policy is not clear about this so if you're charged fees for the return then you should contact Amazon to have them correct it."

Which in no way in hell i would do because i aint paying for shipping for a defective product. I called amazon and they said they‚Äôll refund it. Bought myself a brand new acer nitro instead. Now im scared if that laptop would be defective too."
2402,"First, let me say that I have the version with the 1650Ti, not the 3050. Mine also includes the Webcam, full RGB keyboard, and num pad. There is a slim version that does not have this.Now, I bought this laptop to replace my old daily driver that had a 1050. This laptop is miles better than that one in terms of image quality, GPU power, screen refresh, and sound.I've been using this laptop daily since I bought it. I added a 1TB SSD for storage, upgraded the RAM from the included 8GB to 32GB, and dropped the refresh rate to 60Hz to help battery life (which I will get to later).As far as this goes as a gaming laptop, I've been able to run everything I've thrown at it at max settings. Fallout 76 runs at a solid 48fps (its capped there for some strange reason) at max settings. Gears 5 runs at 60fps (again, capped) on max settings even with all the environment and snow particles. With the IPS display, these games look super good. Huge upgrade to my previous laptops TN display. The colors are absolutely crisp and deep.The sound quality is decent. It's not studio music quality, but it's definitely decent enough for gaming without any noticeable clipping issues. I'm able to discern bass, mid, and treble without a lot of muddiness. Obviously, it's not perfect as they are laptop speakers, but given that restriction, I'd say it does very well.Now, the only complaint I have is the battery life. It's nowhere near the advertised. My old laptop with adjusted settings reached 6-7 hours. This one with the same settings reaches only MAYBE 2. If you're playing a game, you'll be lucky to hit an hour. This is not a laptop to play on battery. The higher the graphic quality and the higher you keep the refresh rate (like the native 144hz) the worse it'll be. Even with dropping the refresh to 60 and playing a game that doesn't require the 1650Ti, it still only will last about an hour. Watching videos is longer, but that's still about 2 hours, give or take.Overall a good purchase provided you want it plugged in most of the time."
2403,"No issues so far, great laptop for the price. The larger screen I love; I did do an upgrade to 16GB DDR4 and added 1T secondary m2, still have room for a standard SSD if I want.The upgrade wasn't a required upgrade just something I did to make it a bit more future proof and expand so I could also use it for work.Even with the upgrade the price is below 1100.00 for a very capable Gaming machine.Playing Fallout 4 before the upgrade I was using Ultimate settings and it never slowed down or stuttered.You do sometimes notice the fans spin a bit faster but that's to be expected. It doesn't get hot that I have found, it's heavy but again to be expected; it's built to be tough, to take the bumps and bangs a laptop gets and keep on going.Looks great to, I do notice some fingerprints/palmprints leaving marks but a quick wipe-down removes them."

2406,"So I got this to play FF14 while I travel and am away from my actual gaming PC, and this does the job perfectly. It's just generally a really capable laptop -- handles streaming, gaming, did some remote work and calls on it np, etc.I love how lightweight and quiet it is.There was only one initial problem I had with it which would have been a deal breaker if there hadn't been such an easy solution -- while I was waiting in that 4k+ q that's the current reality (as of the EW expac), this pc's fans started going haywire.. SOOO loud, heated up, unacceptable. To fix: simply adjust your maximum power state. Docking it a mere 2% will stop it from making any insane noises and return it to the silent, smooth state it runs in when doing everything else (only had the problem when running games, but again super easy fix.  (if you don't know how to adjust this or what that means this is how you fix: Right click your lil battery icon, hit power options, next to the ""ASUS Recommended"" power plan click ""change plan settings"", ""change advanced power settings"", ""processor power management"", ""maximum power state"" -- reduce this from 100% to 98%. Problem solved, resume quiet, beautiful laptop fun)."
2407,"I got this computer to replace an older HP that had gotten slow and lacked Bluetooth. It works better than I could have hoped! The keyboard is excellent. A responsive keyboard is very important to me, and this one does not disappoint. Connected to Wi-Fi effortlessly, Bluetooth is a breeze. I find very few differences between WIN 10 on my old laptop to the WIN 11 here. I highly recommend it! My main use is leisure - email, some minimal graphic and video creation, and surfing the Internet. This little gem keeps up with my multitasking easily."
2408,"This is my first new Windows laptop in nearly eight years; the previous one is a Dell Inspiron 15R that has seen several upgrades and parts replaced but badly needed to be retired.  I had intended on getting an Inspiron 15 5510 with 16GB of RAM and a 1TB SSD but the price just wasn't right.  I settled for this system with the AMD Ryzen 7 and a 512GB SSD.Unboxing the laptop made me think I made a huge mistake.  This is much smaller than my 15R.  I knew thinness coming into it as well as weight; this is a full pound and a half lighter than the 15R, and that will go a long way in the future (more on that later).  It didn't look like a 15"" laptop, but it really is.The screen is a touchscreen.  I used it only once just to see how it worked.  It works.  I don't ever intend on using it ever again because I do not like fingerprints on my laptop screen and I don't think a touchscreen is a useful feature on a laptop.  It is a higher resolution screen than the 15R but it is not the best in the world.  Granted, my M1 MacBook Air has a smaller screen but it is so freaking sharp and amazing, so much so that I think it blows away every other laptop screen on the market.  The screen on this is not a dealbreaker; I don't intend on using the laptop to watch Netflix or any TV shows or whatnot.  It is going to be used exactly what a computer is intended to be used.The keyboard is really nice.  I had destroyed the original keyboard on the 15R and ordered a replacement off Amazon.  It was the loudest keyboard in the world and sometimes some keys just wouldn't type.  I also could not upgrade to a backlit one (again, another MacBook feature I love).  Both the 5510 and 5515 I was looking at had backlit keyboards, and that was a must-have for me.  This one is much quieter, exactly how a laptop keyboard should sound.  F5 to refresh needed to push the Fn key then F5, but then I learned through Google you can make it so that when you hit the refresh key you can make that a primary function.The power cord is a 65W AC adapter with a much smaller plug; not compatible with what I had for the 15R.  I'll be purchasing a second one for travel.  I'm not so sure I'll use the USB-C port to charge the battery and power the laptop while traveling.  I may end up doing that.In terms of USB ports and all, it's nice that there is an HDMI port, one USB-C, and two USB-A ports.  One of the big selling points for me was that it also had an SD card reader.  That in itself seems like something many laptops being sold in 2022 are being shipped without, forcing the user to buy a potentially costly SD card reader of some sort or USB-C multi-hub.  I wish I had one more USB-A port but that would probably add some weight to the laptop.  I'll be buying a pair of USB-A hubs at some point, one for home and one for travel, especially since I need one USB-A for a wireless mouse (though I might look into Bluetooth mice).Weight was another factor in the purchase.  I originally had my eye on the 5510 because it started at 3.6 pounds.  My 15R was somewhere around 5.1 pounds.  Let me say that this 5515 is a pleasure to carry around.  As a videographer who travels quite a bit by airline, my travel backpack weighs in around 30 pounds with a reduced camera load, which includes PC and Mac and accessories and your typical toiletries.  Making that bag 1.5 pounds lighter will feel real good.  I also had an eye on a custom build HP 15t-dy200, which weighed in around 3.8 pounds, but HP has a ton of issues with custom builds as per comments I've seen on Reddit.Finally, expandability.  I have a MacBook Air that I regret not having 16GB of RAM, but even with 8GB it is one hell of an amazing machine, one that no PC out there today could match.  The Dell Inspiron 15 5515 I got has 16GB of RAM and a 512GB SSD.  I really wanted a 1TB SSD but settled for the 512GB.  The memory can be expanded to a max of 32GB (two 16GB sticks) and I plan to do that in the future.  The real kicker is learning that the 5515 (and probably the 5510 as well) has room for a second SSD.  I plan to research this a little more because I definitely want to add a second SSD.  It's a type of SSD that I had never heard about until I researched it, and I'm pretty sure the second SSD can be no larger than 2TB.Overall, with writing this only 30 hours since it arrived, I really like this laptop.  I hope I can get many years out of this like I did with my previous Dell."

2419,"I figured 4GB of RAM would be sufficient just for day to day use. I was a bit disappointed in 128GB of storage and decided that even though it was a really nice machine for the price, for another $80 and change I could really make it fly.. if you look at my photos you can see that there's built in space for a 2.5 in SATA drive. If you look at the pictures I posted you can see that the Acer storage is depleted by half as soon as you turn the machine on. The Steve drive is the one that I installed. Plenty of storage now. The circled in red photo shows the increase in RAM... WHEN LOOKING FOR INSTRUCTIONS be aware that this model came out back in May of this year. There are very few instructional videos or written pieces to explain where this memory goes. The SATA drive is pretty self-explanatory. The only video I could find with this particular machine is provided by a user whose name is.  ¬†@Silicon Edge¬†  you have to go to YouTube and search that name. I don't believe Amazon would allow me to post a link. It's not in English but all you have to do is watch his hands. If you try other videos you might think it's the machine you've bought until you open the back of yours and you look at the back of theirs and realize that it's different. I highly recommend temporarily taking out the screw on your right side of the battery to secure the ribbon clip. Then just readjust the battery and put the screw back in. Watch the video you'll know exactly what I mean. I love this computer. For $460 including the new ram I upgraded this machine. It would have cost me way more than that to buy it with that memory and that storage from scratch. Quick PS. I bought an HP 27 inch monitor here on Amazon and created a nice little setup. $169. You'll love the machine Don't think twice just buy it. If you want some speed, I mean real speed just upgrade the RAM and the storage. I used crucial. That's the brand name for the SATA and the RAM..... READ ABOUT THE UPGRADES..... You don't want to perform Overkill. The processor wasn't made for it. I'm no techie so I did a lot of reading before I did this."

2466,"This zippy laptop has a great screen, nice keyboard/trackpad, good battery, lightweight, plenty of RAM and storage -- an excellent budget 15.6 inch laptop.  This is a RECOMMEND -- especially if it's on sale.But it has two shortcomings worth knowing --1.  I wouldn't recommend this for someone who moves around with their laptop 24 hours a day.  I'm not saying it's flimsy but it's also not 'tough' like a business laptop.  But since I'll typically be using it in my home it's very nice for the price.2.  The real problem (which can be easily fixed by you) is super WEIRD.  I've purchased two of these.  The first one had the issue, I returned it, but then the second one had it too.Believe it or not:  installing Google Chrome can make the OLED screen fail.  (See picture.)I know this because I accidentally noticed the screen 'failed' when I installed Chrome on the first one.  I observed this anecdotally, not actually blaming Chrome.  So I returned that laptop, ordered a 2nd one, and that screen crashed PRECISELY when I installed Google Chrome.That is evidence that it's a software problem, not the OLED.  So I Googled 'Chrome breaks my Asus laptop screen' and Asus offers you advice on how to turn off 'hardware acceleration'.(It's easy, anyone can do it.  Go here -- rb.gy/riuezq)  It also claims this same issue can be triggered by their own Edge browser and by Microsoft Office.  Turn off hardware acceleration and you're all set.  I'm going to 'test' this unit to make sure it's fixed but it sure seems so.  (I told you it was weird.)I suspect others are not reporting this (yet) because they haven't updated to Windows 11 yet, which this unit can do."

The USB-C cannot charge, it is only for data transmission.- It has 2 USB 2.0 and 1 USB 3.0 ports. 2482,"Reading the reviews for this PC, I was expecting this laptop to sound like it's about to take off at mach 5, but it's really not that loud compared to a struggling older PC or an original PS4 pro whose fan is overworked on newer games. Sure it's not quiet by any means, but not nearly as distracting as I anticipated. Performs well but does get pretty warm during intensive gaming even with an additional cooling pad underneath, so definitely get one of those. The weirdest thing is that when you plug or unplug your charger, the screen goes black for a couple of seconds, presumably due to switching power settings. Shouldn't be an issue during gaming sessions however as of course you should have it plugged in for performance anyway, but something to be wary of if your charger cable ever starts to go out. Internal memory isn't huge so I did buy an additional 4TB SSD, which installed smoothly.
