2484,"First, let me say that I have the version with the 1650Ti, not the 3050. Mine also includes the Webcam, full RGB keyboard, and num pad. There is a slim version that does not have this.Now, I bought this laptop to replace my old daily driver that had a 1050. This laptop is miles better than that one in terms of image quality, GPU power, screen refresh, and sound.I've been using this laptop daily since I bought it. I added a 1TB SSD for storage, upgraded the RAM from the included 8GB to 32GB, and dropped the refresh rate to 60Hz to help battery life (which I will get to later).As far as this goes as a gaming laptop, I've been able to run everything I've thrown at it at max settings. Fallout 76 runs at a solid 48fps (its capped there for some strange reason) at max settings. Gears 5 runs at 60fps (again, capped) on max settings even with all the environment and snow particles. With the IPS display, these games look super good. Huge upgrade to my previous laptops TN display. The colors are absolutely crisp and deep.The sound quality is decent. It's not studio music quality, but it's definitely decent enough for gaming without any noticeable clipping issues. I'm able to discern bass, mid, and treble without a lot of muddiness. Obviously, it's not perfect as they are laptop speakers, but given that restriction, I'd say it does very well.Now, the only complaint I have is the battery life. It's nowhere near the advertised. My old laptop with adjusted settings reached 6-7 hours. This one with the same settings reaches only MAYBE 2. If you're playing a game, you'll be lucky to hit an hour. This is not a laptop to play on battery. The higher the graphic quality and the higher you keep the refresh rate (like the native 144hz) the worse it'll be. Even with dropping the refresh to 60 and playing a game that doesn't require the 1650Ti, it still only will last about an hour. Watching videos is longer, but that's still about 2 hours, give or take.Overall a good purchase provided you want it plugged in most of the time."

2488,"So I got this to play FF14 while I travel and am away from my actual gaming PC, and this does the job perfectly. It's just generally a really capable laptop -- handles streaming, gaming, did some remote work and calls on it np, etc.I love how lightweight and quiet it is.There was only one initial problem I had with it which would have been a deal breaker if there hadn't been such an easy solution -- while I was waiting in that 4k+ q that's the current reality (as of the EW expac), this pc's fans started going haywire.. SOOO loud, heated up, unacceptable. To fix: simply adjust your maximum power state. Docking it a mere 2% will stop it from making any insane noises and return it to the silent, smooth state it runs in when doing everything else (only had the problem when running games, but again super easy fix.  (if you don't know how to adjust this or what that means this is how you fix: Right click your lil battery icon, hit power options, next to the ""ASUS Recommended"" power plan click ""change plan settings"", ""change advanced power settings"", ""processor power management"", ""maximum power state"" -- reduce this from 100% to 98%. Problem solved, resume quiet, beautiful laptop fun)."

2490,"This is my first new Windows laptop in nearly eight years; the previous one is a Dell Inspiron 15R that has seen several upgrades and parts replaced but badly needed to be retired.  I had intended on getting an Inspiron 15 5510 with 16GB of RAM and a 1TB SSD but the price just wasn't right.  I settled for this system with the AMD Ryzen 7 and a 512GB SSD.Unboxing the laptop made me think I made a huge mistake.  This is much smaller than my 15R.  I knew thinness coming into it as well as weight; this is a full pound and a half lighter than the 15R, and that will go a long way in the future (more on that later).  It didn't look like a 15"" laptop, but it really is.The screen is a touchscreen.  I used it only once just to see how it worked.  It works.  I don't ever intend on using it ever again because I do not like fingerprints on my laptop screen and I don't think a touchscreen is a useful feature on a laptop.  It is a higher resolution screen than the 15R but it is not the best in the world.  Granted, my M1 MacBook Air has a smaller screen but it is so freaking sharp and amazing, so much so that I think it blows away every other laptop screen on the market.  The screen on this is not a dealbreaker; I don't intend on using the laptop to watch Netflix or any TV shows or whatnot.  It is going to be used exactly what a computer is intended to be used.The keyboard is really nice.  I had destroyed the original keyboard on the 15R and ordered a replacement off Amazon.  It was the loudest keyboard in the world and sometimes some keys just wouldn't type.  I also could not upgrade to a backlit one (again, another MacBook feature I love).  Both the 5510 and 5515 I was looking at had backlit keyboards, and that was a must-have for me.  This one is much quieter, exactly how a laptop keyboard should sound.  F5 to refresh needed to push the Fn key then F5, but then I learned through Google you can make it so that when you hit the refresh key you can make that a primary function.The power cord is a 65W AC adapter with a much smaller plug; not compatible with what I had for the 15R.  I'll be purchasing a second one for travel.  I'm not so sure I'll use the USB-C port to charge the battery and power the laptop while traveling.  I may end up doing that.In terms of USB ports and all, it's nice that there is an HDMI port, one USB-C, and two USB-A ports.  One of the big selling points for me was that it also had an SD card reader.  That in itself seems like something many laptops being sold in 2022 are being shipped without, forcing the user to buy a potentially costly SD card reader of some sort or USB-C multi-hub.  I wish I had one more USB-A port but that would probably add some weight to the laptop.  I'll be buying a pair of USB-A hubs at some point, one for home and one for travel, especially since I need one USB-A for a wireless mouse (though I might look into Bluetooth mice).Weight was another factor in the purchase.  I originally had my eye on the 5510 because it started at 3.6 pounds.  My 15R was somewhere around 5.1 pounds.  Let me say that this 5515 is a pleasure to carry around.  As a videographer who travels quite a bit by airline, my travel backpack weighs in around 30 pounds with a reduced camera load, which includes PC and Mac and accessories and your typical toiletries.  Making that bag 1.5 pounds lighter will feel real good.  I also had an eye on a custom build HP 15t-dy200, which weighed in around 3.8 pounds, but HP has a ton of issues with custom builds as per comments I've seen on Reddit.Finally, expandability.  I have a MacBook Air that I regret not having 16GB of RAM, but even with 8GB it is one hell of an amazing machine, one that no PC out there today could match.  The Dell Inspiron 15 5515 I got has 16GB of RAM and a 512GB SSD.  I really wanted a 1TB SSD but settled for the 512GB.  The memory can be expanded to a max of 32GB (two 16GB sticks) and I plan to do that in the future.  The real kicker is learning that the 5515 (and probably the 5510 as well) has room for a second SSD.  I plan to research this a little more because I definitely want to add a second SSD.  It's a type of SSD that I had never heard about until I researched it, and I'm pretty sure the second SSD can be no larger than 2TB.Overall, with writing this only 30 hours since it arrived, I really like this laptop.  I hope I can get many years out of this like I did with my previous Dell."

2502,"I recently ordered five ‚Äúrenewed‚Äù iPad Air 2 tablets through Amazon.¬†¬†The Air 2 was, and still is, one of the best iPad designs.¬†¬†So good, in fact, that the first iPad Pro 9.7 (2018) was really just an updated Air 2 and shared the same thin construction, laminated 9.7-inch Retina display, and overall size.¬†¬†The Air 2 has supported seven iOS updates and currently runs the latest iPadOS¬†14 ‚Äìtalk about longevity.¬† Over 2 million iPad Air 2 models were sold during its two year production that ended in early 2017.¬†Since you can no longer buy a new Air 2, the only option is used/refurbished.¬† Apple devices like the iPad are remarkably durable and buying refurbished is a great way to find a ""like new"" device that will last you many years to come.¬† It's a good value, too: When the Air 2 was originally released, the models ranged from $500-$700.¬† A few years later, you can buy the same models renewed for $200-$300 --a great deal for a device that's still state-of-the-art.¬†There's¬†no shortage of vendors for renewed/refurbished iPads but one thing is clear:¬†¬†‚ÄúRenewed, like new‚Äù is a broad term that covers everything from near-mint condition to laughingly-damaged devices.¬†¬†Some vendors are better, others are worse,¬†none will be perfect.¬†¬†Here‚Äôs my experience shopping over the past month:¬†Vendor #1:¬†¬†All Out Apple¬†I purchased two iPad Air 2‚Äôs from this seller, one 32GB and one 64GB.¬†¬†Both arrived in good condition, packaged safely, and they work fine.¬†¬†The¬†cosmetic defects are OK --a few light scratches and discoloration on the back of the case on one and a few nicks and shallow dent on the back of the other.¬†¬†When held at ‚Äúarm‚Äôs length‚Äù per Amazon's criteria the issues are not that visible.¬†¬†The display/touchscreenS are fine.¬†¬†The batteries in each last the normal 8 or so hours under typical use. The vendor includes a decent 2.4A (12W) USB charger and cable with each device similar to¬†the original iPad charger for fast charging times.¬†¬†Vendor #2:¬†¬†Platinum Deals[UPDATED 3/6/21:  I purchased four iPad Air 2‚Äôs from this seller, three 32GB and one 64GB.¬†¬†One of the 32GB arrived in close to ""like new"" condition.¬†¬†The cosmetic defects were minimal, however, after two weeks use, I noticed that a portion of the display backlight would flicker when set to the lowest brightness setting --the sign of a failing LED in the backlight.  I returned this iPad for another from same seller and the replacement works fine so far.  However, the cosmetic condition of the replacement is not as good as the first one since there are noticeable blemishes all the way around the aluminum bezel and there are a couple light scratches on the surface of the display glass.]  The other two iPads were, unfortunately, a totally¬†different story:¬† each one was delivered literally bent in the middle --not dented but actually deformed, as in the device was not flat!¬† This had nothing to do with shipping since the devices were¬†well-packed and the boxes were undamaged.¬† The deformation on each device distorted the display glass and it was easy to¬†see the permanent distortion when viewing along the edge of the device.¬† On one iPad, the deformation was severe enough to cause backlight distortion that¬†showed up as bright spots along the edge of the LCD (see photos).¬† The fact that the refurbisher considered these two bent iPads to be ""renewed, like new"" is both hilarious and sad.¬† Of course, both of the bent iPads went right back in their boxes for return to Amazon (I put a bright yellow post-it on each one to hopefully warn whoever inspects the returned devices not to turn around and sell them again.)¬† This vendor also included different USB chargers (either 8W or 12W USB-A or, incorrectly, one of them was USB-C) and cable with each device so they are not consistent --the 12W charger is the correct one for faster charging times.  I do give the vendor credit for immediately sending me the correct charger to replace the wrong USB-C charger delivered with one of the Air 2 units.ADVICE:  So, my advice is to inspect your ""renewed"" iPad carefully since the vendors are not consistent in the overall condition of what they'll send you.¬† The iPad Air 2, in particular, is remarkably thin and perhaps more prone to getting bent if mishandled during its life --perhaps explaining why bent ones find their way to a refurbisher in the first place.  The Air 2 has a wide tolerance for being bent and still work without a problem. However, it's quite clear that ""like new"" may not necessarily mean ""not bent"" for the ultra-thin Air 2 so use the 90-day Amazon Renewed Guarantee wisely to make sure your renewed device meets a reasonable definition of ""like new"" upon receipt.Overall, I'm happy with the two renewed iPads I decided to keep (32GB models, one from each vendor listed above).¬† I'm not sure that¬†any one vendor does a¬†better¬†job in selecting ""like new"" iPads but clearly, one of the above did not have an issue sending two bent iPads.Finally, be aware that the 90-day Amazon Renewed Guarantee says you'll get a full refund if not satisfied, however, some of the refurb vendors claim to charge return shipping and restocking fees.¬† The Amazon Renewed policy is not clear about this so if you're charged fees for the return then you should contact Amazon to have them correct it."

This was just a defective product with a ticking time bomb. Don't be tempted by the ""certified refurbished"" label. It is not the same as a manufacturer's certification, which typically does have rigorous standards and solid warranties. I take immaculate care of my things, and am not sure what caused it. Browsing forums and Reddit, it appears this is a common issue with MSI keyboards. It is super easy to replace, and you can do so for $10. But the fact I paid almost $2,000 for a laptop, and the keys pop off at their own will is something to consider. I have passed my replacement window at this point, and the best Amazon could do was offer 10% of my money back. Outside of that, this machine is a beast."
2549,"OK, this is my second unit, but it is beautiful and everything works right out of the box.Note: the first unit shipped to me by Amazon had about a 10 inch crack diagonally across the display when I opened it right out of the box and powered it up.  I've seen numerous videos of reviewers tossing these LG Grams down a set of concrete stairs, bouncing and tumbling.. and then they pick it up and it turn back on and works.  So.. this clearly was some sort of factory defect that escaped LG.  NOW.. this is why I love Amazon... because I immediately contacted customer support to request an exchange and they had an new unit allocated to me immediately, which shipped the next morning.  No fuss, no muss... just the usual outstanding Amazon customer service.  But this only works if the item is sold by Amazon, not 3rd parties.. so I always make sure that when buying expensive electronics on Amazon.... I only by directly from Amazon, NOT 3rd parties.On to the second unit, which works and is perfect in workmanship and finish.  Powered up the unit and it immediately did the now famous Windows 10 configuration dialog and sequences.  Took only a few minutes, and then it was up and ready to go.  It performed a series of driver updates, and OS updates to bring it current, all without flaw and almost transparent to me, save for the need to log in after it did an after hours reboot to bring the OS updates online.Let me take a moment to comment on LG packaging of the unit.  The package is a very compact, very sleek, yet perfect protection for the unit in shipment.  LG has outstanding packaging design teams, and that goes right down to the box they ship product in.  Box is double sealed with LG security tape, with a note to refuse to accept the item if the seals are broken.Unit comes with a USB C power unit, power cord for the unit, and a quick get started booklet of a few pages.  Everything else is on the machine itself.Battery was about 70% charged upon receipt, so I immediately got a chance to see the unit top up the power to full.. and while doing so... it draws a lot of power from the little power unit, so both the underside of the notebook and the power unit will get warm during battery charging. But once the battery is full charge, everything cools down.  So just be aware that the power unit will get warm when the battery is charging.  There may be some setting adjustments to tone the rate of charge down, but I have not yet delved into the LG specific apps and features for managing the computer.The keyboard is fantastic in the 2021 LG Gram lineup, as is the new track pad design (though I prefer to use a mouse most of the time), and is quite functional and crisp if you are a trackpad user.While sound is not typically an LG Gram strong suit, I have to say the sound system in the 2021s is a step up from prior years models.All in, LG very much appears to be on a consistent path to keep in making LG Grams better and better every year.It still boggles the mind how a 16 inch notebook can be so light weight, thin, and yet rugged in design.  I was a bit skeptical about the new aspect ratio (16:10) of the 16 inch screen (same as Apple does), but I am now sold on it.  Plenty of screen in a form factor that is actually a bit smaller than last years LG Gram 15 inch units.Time will tell how this notebook does longer term, but if LGs reputation for their Gram line is any indicator.. it will have a long and reliable life.  There are after all, no moving parts in an LG Gram other than the keyboard and the hinge for the display.  Everything else is completely solid state.  RAM is soldered to the board (a requirement for the new generation ram that goes with the gen 11 Intel processors), and there is a single 1 tera byte SSD.Happily LG does not load up their Grams with a lot of bloatware.  From my perspective, the only programs that need to be immediately purged from the machine is McAfee LiveSafe 30 day trial (I prefer to use the tandem combo of Windows Security and Malwarebytes Premium), and Office 365 trial (I prefer a licensed copy of Office installed on my machines, not Office 365).  Other than that, everything looks tight and clean on the disk image from the factory.I plan to let the machine stay powered up for the next week to insure that there are no early component issues, and then I will be moving files from my old computer to this one and expect to be completely on the new LG Gram  from then on."
2550,"Been playing around with the 16 inch version for several weeks now. build-wise I am very pleased. The screen doesn't wobble too much and the keyboard is just lovely to use. I will say there's one potential issue, where if you put enough weight/pressure on the space left or right of the touch pad, you can get it to register as a click, but in practical use it never happened. Something to watch out for if you have massive sausage arms that lay flat on the laptop, maybe. That aside, I REALLY like the trackpad. It's been like a decade since I used a laptop pad so I was assuming a mouse would be a mandatory purchase, but not anymore. The multi-touch controls work great, and it's nice and big so I never feel like my fingers are gravitating too far into a corner to browse properly.On the software side of things I am impressed with the SSD and operating system. Once you got your user settings entered the first time around, the computer can go from the powered-off state to your home screen in like fifteen seconds. I haven't extensively tested the CPU, though I've found it can run Overwatch at low settings and 60fps with only minimal tinkering.  I primarily use it for writing and the occasional google research/time waster, which it handles with ease, and I'm sure it could stream a Spotify setlise or play iTunes on top of that as well. It also didn't seem like a big deal at first, but the fingerprint scanner is so nifty to have, I have actually become spoiled on it and feel irritated when I have to type my password out on the desktop.There are some ""bloatware"" applications pre-installed that you could do without, such as McCaffee, but mostly the applications seem fine. There's the LG Virtoo app that can sync to an LG phone, which I also happen to have. Testing it...I mean, it works, you can send/receive calls through the laptop and copy over any photos you've taken, but the bluetooth connectivity would kill your phone battery with any extensive use, and the sound/mic quality on the Gram is not professional by any means. Far more useful is the simple control panel that has your power features, screen brightness and fan options at just a click away. There's also an LG-branded video editor, though given the Gram's low voltage and integrated graphics, I doubt you'd want to compile any 4k footage on this laptop.There's only a handful of nitpicks bring it down to a 4/5. Main thing is, for whatever reason, I can't get it to save separate power usage/brightness settings depending on whether it's plugged in or not. This is quickly fixed by clicking the battery on the taskbar and using the hotkeys to change the screen's brightness, but it is irksome to do it EVERY single time. Secondly, if you use the Gram at a less than full charge while charging, the charger brick gets surprisingly warm. I'd say it's hot, even. Lastly, the screen is really glossy. As a cave-dwelling hermit this doesn't affect me, but I can imagine using this in an outdoor setting or coffee shop with a bunch of overhead lamps might not be the best experience.Can I recommend this absurdly expensive laptop to everyone? Well, no. It fits my niche of needing a super lightweight quiet writing device with a decent screen size, easily capable of some research googles or wasting time with very light gaming sessions. In this regard I am super satisfied. If you need something for gaming, media production or media consumption, there are cheaper, better options available."
2551,"I bought this laptop because I really liked an LG Gram that I bought a few years ago, and wanted an upgrade with a bigger screen and more RAM. So far I've been disappointed. I have a few issues with this laptop, though hopefully the main one will be fixed soon and it's probably not entirely LG's fault:My main issue is that audio calls (Zoom etc.) sound quite bad when using the built-in speakers -- much worse than using my old Gram. The audio is quiet and muffled, and if I turn up the sound the sound starts breaking up a bit. After googling some, I found that other people are having this issue on other laptops with Windows 11 (I cannot provide links in Amazon reviews, but you can search to find them). It seems that with some other laptop manufacturers, there is now an audio driver that fixes the problem, but I am fully updated with LG drivers and I still have this issue. I will likely have to send the laptop back to LG.My secondary issue is that the battery life is just OK. For example, after 3 hours of Teams and Zoom calls, the battery was pretty much entirely drained. I know that the ""22 hours of battery life"" is not meant to be while on high brightness and doing video calls, but still 3 hours is not very impressive. I think my old Gram still does somewhat better than this.Other than that, I feel that this can be a nice laptop. It's light and has a big screen, and the performance seems good overall. But I recommend not buying it until LG at least provides drivers that fix the sound issue. Otherwise, video calls sound terrible."

2575,"I recently ordered five ‚Äúrenewed‚Äù iPad Air 2 tablets through Amazon.¬†¬†The Air 2 was, and still is, one of the best iPad designs.¬†¬†So good, in fact, that the first iPad Pro 9.7 (2018) was really just an updated Air 2 and shared the same thin construction, laminated 9.7-inch Retina display, and overall size.¬†¬†The Air 2 has supported seven iOS updates and currently runs the latest iPadOS¬†14 ‚Äìtalk about longevity.¬† Over 2 million iPad Air 2 models were sold during its two year production that ended in early 2017.¬†Since you can no longer buy a new Air 2, the only option is used/refurbished.¬† Apple devices like the iPad are remarkably durable and buying refurbished is a great way to find a ""like new"" device that will last you many years to come.¬† It's a good value, too: When the Air 2 was originally released, the models ranged from $500-$700.¬† A few years later, you can buy the same models renewed for $200-$300 --a great deal for a device that's still state-of-the-art.¬†There's¬†no shortage of vendors for renewed/refurbished iPads but one thing is clear:¬†¬†‚ÄúRenewed, like new‚Äù is a broad term that covers everything from near-mint condition to laughingly-damaged devices.¬†¬†Some vendors are better, others are worse,¬†none will be perfect.¬†¬†Here‚Äôs my experience shopping over the past month:¬†Vendor #1:¬†¬†All Out Apple¬†I purchased two iPad Air 2‚Äôs from this seller, one 32GB and one 64GB.¬†¬†Both arrived in good condition, packaged safely, and they work fine.¬†¬†The¬†cosmetic defects are OK --a few light scratches and discoloration on the back of the case on one and a few nicks and shallow dent on the back of the other.¬†¬†When held at ‚Äúarm‚Äôs length‚Äù per Amazon's criteria the issues are not that visible.¬†¬†The display/touchscreenS are fine.¬†¬†The batteries in each last the normal 8 or so hours under typical use. The vendor includes a decent 2.4A (12W) USB charger and cable with each device similar to¬†the original iPad charger for fast charging times.¬†¬†Vendor #2:¬†¬†Platinum Deals[UPDATED 3/6/21:  I purchased four iPad Air 2‚Äôs from this seller, three 32GB and one 64GB.¬†¬†One of the 32GB arrived in close to ""like new"" condition.¬†¬†The cosmetic defects were minimal, however, after two weeks use, I noticed that a portion of the display backlight would flicker when set to the lowest brightness setting --the sign of a failing LED in the backlight.  I returned this iPad for another from same seller and the replacement works fine so far.  However, the cosmetic condition of the replacement is not as good as the first one since there are noticeable blemishes all the way around the aluminum bezel and there are a couple light scratches on the surface of the display glass.]  The other two iPads were, unfortunately, a totally¬†different story:¬† each one was delivered literally bent in the middle --not dented but actually deformed, as in the device was not flat!¬† This had nothing to do with shipping since the devices were¬†well-packed and the boxes were undamaged.¬† The deformation on each device distorted the display glass and it was easy to¬†see the permanent distortion when viewing along the edge of the device.¬† On one iPad, the deformation was severe enough to cause backlight distortion that¬†showed up as bright spots along the edge of the LCD (see photos).¬† The fact that the refurbisher considered these two bent iPads to be ""renewed, like new"" is both hilarious and sad.¬† Of course, both of the bent iPads went right back in their boxes for return to Amazon (I put a bright yellow post-it on each one to hopefully warn whoever inspects the returned devices not to turn around and sell them again.)¬† This vendor also included different USB chargers (either 8W or 12W USB-A or, incorrectly, one of them was USB-C) and cable with each device so they are not consistent --the 12W charger is the correct one for faster charging times.  I do give the vendor credit for immediately sending me the correct charger to replace the wrong USB-C charger delivered with one of the Air 2 units.ADVICE:  So, my advice is to inspect your ""renewed"" iPad carefully since the vendors are not consistent in the overall condition of what they'll send you.¬† The iPad Air 2, in particular, is remarkably thin and perhaps more prone to getting bent if mishandled during its life --perhaps explaining why bent ones find their way to a refurbisher in the first place.  The Air 2 has a wide tolerance for being bent and still work without a problem. However, it's quite clear that ""like new"" may not necessarily mean ""not bent"" for the ultra-thin Air 2 so use the 90-day Amazon Renewed Guarantee wisely to make sure your renewed device meets a reasonable definition of ""like new"" upon receipt.Overall, I'm happy with the two renewed iPads I decided to keep (32GB models, one from each vendor listed above).¬† I'm not sure that¬†any one vendor does a¬†better¬†job in selecting ""like new"" iPads but clearly, one of the above did not have an issue sending two bent iPads.Finally, be aware that the 90-day Amazon Renewed Guarantee says you'll get a full refund if not satisfied, however, some of the refurb vendors claim to charge return shipping and restocking fees.¬† The Amazon Renewed policy is not clear about this so if you're charged fees for the return then you should contact Amazon to have them correct it."

2609,"This zippy laptop has a great screen, nice keyboard/trackpad, good battery, lightweight, plenty of RAM and storage -- an excellent budget 15.6 inch laptop. I'm not saying it's flimsy but it's also not 'tough' like a business laptop.  But since I'll typically be using it in my home it's very nice for the price.2.  The real problem (which can be easily fixed by you) is super WEIRD.  I've purchased two of these.  The first one had the issue, I returned it, but then the second one had it too.Believe it or not:  installing Google Chrome can make the OLED screen fail.  (See picture.)I know this because I accidentally noticed the screen 'failed' when I installed Chrome on the first one.  I observed this anecdotally, not actually blaming Chrome.  So I returned that laptop, ordered a 2nd one, and that screen crashed PRECISELY when I installed Google Chrome.That is evidence that it's a software problem, not the OLED.  So I Googled 'Chrome breaks my Asus laptop screen' and Asus offers you advice on how to turn off 'hardware acceleration'.(It's easy, anyone can do it.  Go here -- rb.gy/riuezq)  It also claims this same issue can be triggered by their own Edge browser and by Microsoft Office.  Turn off hardware acceleration and you're all set.  I'm going to 'test' this unit to make sure it's fixed but it sure seems so.  (I told you it was weird.)I suspect others are not reporting this (yet) because they haven't updated to Windows 11 yet, which this unit can do."

2629,"Reading the reviews for this PC, I was expecting this laptop to sound like it's about to take off at mach 5, but it's really not that loud compared to a struggling older PC or an original PS4 pro whose fan is overworked on newer games. Sure it's not quiet by any means, but not nearly as distracting as I anticipated. Performs well but does get pretty warm during intensive gaming even with an additional cooling pad underneath, so definitely get one of those. The weirdest thing is that when you plug or unplug your charger, the screen goes black for a couple of seconds, presumably due to switching power settings. Shouldn't be an issue during gaming sessions however as of course you should have it plugged in for performance anyway, but something to be wary of if your charger cable ever starts to go out. Internal memory isn't huge so I did buy an additional 4TB SSD, which installed smoothly. 2631,"First, let me say that I have the version with the 1650Ti, not the 3050. Mine also includes the Webcam, full RGB keyboard, and num pad. There is a slim version that does not have this.Now, I bought this laptop to replace my old daily driver that had a 1050. This laptop is miles better than that one in terms of image quality, GPU power, screen refresh, and sound.I've been using this laptop daily since I bought it. I added a 1TB SSD for storage, upgraded the RAM from the included 8GB to 32GB, and dropped the refresh rate to 60Hz to help battery life (which I will get to later).As far as this goes as a gaming laptop, I've been able to run everything I've thrown at it at max settings. Fallout 76 runs at a solid 48fps (its capped there for some strange reason) at max settings. Gears 5 runs at 60fps (again, capped) on max settings even with all the environment and snow particles. With the IPS display, these games look super good. Huge upgrade to my previous laptops TN display. The colors are absolutely crisp and deep.The sound quality is decent. It's not studio music quality, but it's definitely decent enough for gaming without any noticeable clipping issues. I'm able to discern bass, mid, and treble without a lot of muddiness. Obviously, it's not perfect as they are laptop speakers, but given that restriction, I'd say it does very well.Now, the only complaint I have is the battery life. It's nowhere near the advertised. My old laptop with adjusted settings reached 6-7 hours. This one with the same settings reaches only MAYBE 2. If you're playing a game, you'll be lucky to hit an hour. This is not a laptop to play on battery. The higher the graphic quality and the higher you keep the refresh rate (like the native 144hz) the worse it'll be. Even with dropping the refresh to 60 and playing a game that doesn't require the 1650Ti, it still only will last about an hour. Watching videos is longer, but that's still about 2 hours, give or take.Overall a good purchase provided you want it plugged in most of the time."

2635,"So I got this to play FF14 while I travel and am away from my actual gaming PC, and this does the job perfectly. It's just generally a really capable laptop -- handles streaming, gaming, did some remote work and calls on it np, etc.I love how lightweight and quiet it is.There was only one initial problem I had with it which would have been a deal breaker if there hadn't been such an easy solution -- while I was waiting in that 4k+ q that's the current reality (as of the EW expac), this pc's fans started going haywire.. SOOO loud, heated up, unacceptable. To fix: simply adjust your maximum power state. Docking it a mere 2% will stop it from making any insane noises and return it to the silent, smooth state it runs in when doing everything else (only had the problem when running games, but again super easy fix.  (if you don't know how to adjust this or what that means this is how you fix: Right click your lil battery icon, hit power options, next to the ""ASUS Recommended"" power plan click ""change plan settings"", ""change advanced power settings"", ""processor power management"", ""maximum power state"" -- reduce this from 100% to 98%. Problem solved, resume quiet, beautiful laptop fun)."
